title: New Feature: One-time Permaban Buyback
body:
EDIT: If you're going to down vote, please leave your opinion, much appreciated. I don't think my proposals are too crazy of a suggestion.

ATTN: Before you read this, just know I and others are asking for another shot. We're not bad people, we just rage and use foul language at times. 

I and countless others have been toxic, yes, we do not deny this. And then we have gone on and been toxic on new accounts that we have made. Partially because we tend to rage and partially because we had our main accounts banned and harbor resentment towards Riot. My proposition is a fair one, and one that could make Riot a few easy extra bucks here and there. Basically, my proposal is; after having your account permanently banned the first and only time, Riot gives you one last final option to reform. You pay a fine of 50 USD. Now I know you might say, that's too easy, it won't help the community. But instead of saying hey, let's reset all penalties and give a fresh start, by paying 50 dollars you agree to never be toxic again. You get a 10-game counter. If get reported 10 times, and the reports are warranted and you are found guilty, your account is gone forever. The system deletes it, the name is up for grabs, and all your stats, awards, purchases, and everything vanish. 

---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

I have another proposal, a slightly more reasonable one. Instead of jumping from a two-week ban to a permanent ban, which is pretty extreme, Riot adds a 1-month ban, then a 6-month, and then a permanent ban. I just feel, logically, the punishments are disproportionate and illogical. You go from a chat restriction of 10 games, to a 14 day ban, to forever. The escalation is insane and doesn't help to "reform" anyone. Instead, honestly the best punishment would simply be permanent chat restriction, considering most of us toxic players rage at others for playing poorly, we ourselves play pretty well and don't intentionally cause losses, we just use sometimes hurtful words. Blocking messages from sending if they contain offensive words would easily reform us toxic players, because we'd be unable to say anything unless it contained normal language. 

Most of you won't read this, and most of you will just write me off as a toxic player who can't follow the rules. But hey, I'm human, this game gets me angry because this is one of the most time-consuming games, where you can spend 60 minutes toiling for a win and then some asshole decides to do something stupid and you're just supposed to suppress the anger and go gg? My proposals are just ideas, ideas I put some thought into, ideas that help keep the entire community happy, generate more revenue, and so on.

I spent over 1000 USD on my main account, which was permabanned. I haven't spent a penny since then, and have even been reported and banned for games where I've been ganged up on and reacted to 4-man teams harassing me. One ban flags you for Riot and you get no mercy. I'm just asking for more options and a way to still be able to play on my account that I spent so much time and money on.

replies.body:
If you can't reform after the warnings, you don't deserve to come back.

Plus, Riot already tried something similar. Perma-banned users could contact Riot about joining a thing where if they could get to level 20 without being reported once, their original account would get unbanned. 80 or 90% of those people failed and got reported before level 20.

Be happy Riot allows you to make a new account after being perma banned.

I actually like that. They should have kept that program. It would at least make those that made all the more worthy, and that's completely attainable. I don't know how people couldn't make it to 20, haha.

Perma-ban is designed to remove players from the game. We no longer want them playing League of Legends because they hurt the experience of others.

The result of the experiment was actually 95% of the players being permabanned again. Not 80-90% getting reported before level 20.

The current punishment levels are as they are because if a player does not change their behavior after multiple warnings, they are not likely to change. We used to have other punishment levels in place, but all it did was delay the amount of time until a player arrived at perma-ban status. It did not help with reform rates, and ultimately allowed more games to be ruined.

There are diminishing reform rates at each level of penalty. The majority of players who get a chat restriction, never get any other penalty. Additionally, the vast majority of players never get any sort of penalty at all. Players that get penalties of any sort are by far the outlier.

[EDIT: Honestly, just adding an option to turnoff in-game chat would significantly reduce the urge to rage. The option would be in the client so you couldn't flick it back on in-game. Boom. Another deterrent. You can't be toxic if you can't talk. But keep telling me banning accounts is better than permanently chat block, it makes so much sense.

I may eventually spend money on this game again, but until that time I'm just a freeloader clogging up your servers and shitting on your noobs. Yeah, I get I can be an asshole, but being nice doesn't get you as far. My poor attitude aside, I make valid points, and you stick to your script, but permanent account bans do nothing to prevent or reform toxicity, we're still here.]

To be fair, I don't even get warnings anymore. I don't know if that has something to do with my Mac client because it's glitchy as hell on macOS/OS X compared to Windows. Again, your statistics are skewed because I highly doubt that you're accounting for players who create a summoner and play a few games and then never play again. Inactive accounts, or accounts sitting at level 30 that take around 2 years to expire, and then people who play consistently. I feel that the average person who gets permabanned plays a significant amount of League each week or month, so you'd have to compare the percentage of those banned to those who play similar amounts of League, day, week, and month. So I'm sure your permabanned community is actually a higher percentage than you make it out to be. 

Tell me how permanently banning me or someone else for being verbally toxic, is more efficient than simply removing our ability to communicate in-game. If you were truthful and aware you'd realize a fraction of the League population actually constructively communicates during the game. So banning that tiny percentage you wave at me from speaking in-game would eradicate your toxicity problem without upsetting anyone. Those with soft skin wouldn't have to deal with us scrutinizing them, and we wouldn't be able to say anything. 

But instead ... I'm forced to make new accounts and I'm far better than entry level players. So they get demolished in early levels and that hinders their learning process and overall enjoyment, also, like I said barely anyone actually communicates, so even when I try to help them, they don't give a shit and don't try to get better. This isn't Halo where someone shitty can pick up a rocket launcher and kill people, you need a bit more intelligence/skill/time to get good at this game.

I'm all for this. Most of in-game chat is either pointless or negative, and what little of it is positive can be done with pings equally well. I don't need to mute myself, but if there are people who think they can't hold their tongues in the heat of the moment, why not provide them the means? No matter how you look at it, it's definitely a win for everybody involved.

Personally I really wish I could tick a box to make the enemy team muted by default, it would really save me several seconds at game start. And even better, a way to show people that I muted them. That way they wouldn't even try to type stuff to me and potentially tilting my teammates.
TL:DR To disable, be in match, 1. Esc 2. Interface 3. Scroll to bottom 4. Chat 5. Uncheck - Show [All] Chat (Matched Games)
I didn't know that, thanks! This saves me a lot of hassle.

If you're verbally toxic, you're more likely to afk, rage quit, int feed, and troll.

We don't need people like that in this game.

But I've never been reported for afk, rage quit, intentionally feeding, or trolling because I don't do those things. It's only verbal toxicity in response to those things you mentioned. I don't join games and go off on people because I'm a maniac. 

Btw, they forum banned my Feniks account. This is one of my other permabanned accounts. ;)

by just going to another account, I'm not getting the feeling you understand the gravity of ACTUALLY GETTING BANNED FROM THE FORUMS. You have to do something big to get that. Also, being set off by those things doesn't mean you're in the right. you're just as wrong as those people.

I don't think you understand that was my point is exactly that, banning accounts doesn't deter verbal toxicity. It doesn't stop it or prevent it. We are free to make another account and all a permaban does is infuriate us. Basically, you have one bad game, it's annoying, then you have five straight bad games and it is insanity. It's annoying and we feel the need to vent our frustration. We could have tens, hundreds, even thousands of games played but if you have even a small percentage you will be punished, doesn't matter how many times you were honored.

PRO TIP: Don't fucking vent out on your team mates. Go punch a pillow. Scream with your mouth covered. Jerk off while anally stimulating yourself. Idc  what you do, there is no excuse to vent out your frustrations on your team mates. If getting perma banned infuriates you just avoid getting perma banned. Being perma'd is not supposed to be a fun experience. If you are not mature enough to do that, go play a single player game.

I've had a number people report me for not going top when I called mid first as, for example, annie, or not doing well with a champ. But I didn't get banned from anything. It takes a lot to get permabanned, and it doesn't matter how many good games you have.
because you can also be toxic by purposely feeding the enemy. Honestly, your idea doesn't say "intelligence" to me.

It doesn't seem that you have an abundance of "intelligence." Intentionally feeding is a separate report. I don't intentionally feed, my reports are based on verbal toxicity. It wasn't explicitly mentioned, but heavily implied.
I was referring to your idea of paying to get preferential treatment, though I should have seen how that could be interpreted incorrectly.

Priceless

Why do you use the logic of banning people because of "ruining games", but you don't do anything about feeders? Tell me why calling an 0/10 teammate "bad" ruins the game more than the fact that they are 0/10.

> [{quoted}](name=The Big Piece,realm=NA,application-id=ZGEFLEUQ,discussion-id=ZZkQvApM,comment-id=0006000000000004,timestamp=2016-11-02T08:49:00.926+0000)

What do you suspect calling them "bad" helps?

> [{quoted}](name=EvilDustMan,realm=NA,application-id=ZGEFLEUQ,discussion-id=ZZkQvApM,comment-id=00060000000000040000,timestamp=2016-11-02T09:24:45.678+0000)
>
> What do you suspect calling them "bad" helps?

My question doesn't have anything to do with whether calling them bad helps or not, I just want to know why one thing that ruins the game, wastes time, takes away LP (feeding/trolling) is NOT punishable, but calling someone "bad" (not nearly as toxic as what you usually see and completely mutable) is punishable.

> [{quoted}](name=The Big Piece,realm=NA,application-id=ZGEFLEUQ,discussion-id=ZZkQvApM,comment-id=000600000000000400000000,timestamp=2016-11-02T09:40:46.938+0000)
>
> My question doesn't have anything to do with whether calling them bad helps or not, I just want to know why one thing that ruins the game, wastes time, takes away LP (feeding/trolling) is NOT punishable, but calling someone "bad" (not nearly as toxic as what you usually see and completely mutable) is punishable.

Intentional feeding, trolling and griefing is punishable and punished. It is punished by a 14 day ban for the first offense.

Only is cases where it is blatantly obvious. Sure people with mobi boots/tear going 0/30 get banned, but going 0/10 won't get anyone banned, but the people who react to it will be. And I'm not saying we should ban anyone who plays terribly, but there should be some consequence to it. Going 0/10 and directly causing a loss doesn't have any different result from your teammate who played perfectly.

> [{quoted}](name=The Big Piece,realm=NA,application-id=ZGEFLEUQ,discussion-id=ZZkQvApM,comment-id=00060000000000040000000000000000,timestamp=2016-11-02T09:51:02.569+0000)
>
> Only is cases where it is blatantly obvious. Sure people with mobi boots/tear going 0/30 get banned, but going 0/10 won't get anyone banned, but the people who react to it will be. And I'm not saying we should ban anyone who plays terribly, but there should be some consequence to it. Going 0/10 and directly causing a loss doesn't have any different result from your teammate who played perfectly.

The detection they have is better than you suspect but not perfect. Regardless, when you suspect someone is feeding or trolling, what does throwing anger at them do?

Best case scenario: Nothing.
More common case scenario: You make things worse.

>Only is cases where it is blatantly obvious.

The same actually applies to chat related toxicity. Both offenses are granted the same benefit of doubt.
The difference between the two is merely the fact that chat related toxicity is inherently obvious because it's based on communication. Communication **tries** to be obvious.
As such, all the relevant data is very well documented and extremely easy to review; be it manually or automatically.

Actually, that isn't the case at all. I don't think anyone could logically consider a factual statement- calling an 0/10 teammate bad to be "blatantly" toxic. Its more about the consistency of it. I suppose you could consider telling people to kill themselves and stuff like that to be blatantly toxic, but not calling someone "bad".

The biggest factor isn't how "toxic" something you say is, but how often you say it. I never called my teammates anything worse than "bad", but because I was matched with feeders very often, I ended getting permabanned after a very long period of time.

> I don't think anyone could logically consider a factual statement- calling an 0/10 teammate bad to be "blatantly" toxic.

Neither did I. I called it blatantly obvious.
"Blatant" can refer to the severity of a negative action, or to the obviousness of it. "Blatantly obvious" on the other hand is fairly unambiguous.

And that's just the thing, Riot doesn't only punish the severe feeders. They punish the **obvious** feeders.

To further elaborate: I've seen a replay of a game that was flagged for intentional feeding. The person in question fed a **single** kill in an entire game. That's not blatant feeding in the way you use the word in regards to verbal toxicity. But it certainly was blatantly obvious, thus is got detected and he got punished for it.

Short version:
Obvious toxicity is punished.
Severe **and** obvious toxicity is punished harshly.

That applies to verbal toxicity and feeding alike.

No, QT being banned for giving Gnar a kill showed how broken the system really is. The system does a very poor job at catching feeders. 

But thats irrelevant to my point anyway. If we want to think that calling a bad player "bad" is banworthy, then ok. But there should be some punishment for being 0/10. Currently there is not.

Because being bad is not worthy of being punished.
The mere fact that you are completely leaving assists out of this shows how shortsighted you are. I've **carried** games while being 1/10 (Braum ftw).

And how is an example of the system being capable of determining a **single** death as being feeding a sign of the system doing a very poor job at catching feeders?
I wasn't even referring to that case. So it seems like this is actually something the system can pull off consistently.

>No if it banned people for dying once

It... doesn't do that?
The system doesn't only look at deaths. You **are** aware of that, right?

>Does anybody truly believe that calling someone "bad" is ruining the game more than the fact that someone is 0/10? I just can't see any legitimate argument for that.

The difference is that one is intentional and one is not (provably) intentional.
Edit: **And** it's not even necessarily ruining the game. Again, the stats 0/10 say absolutely nothing about how that player is peforming.

No if it banned people for dying once, there would be a huge problem. 

Anyway my original point was, if we are banning on the basis of "ruining games", how can anyone consider calling someone "bad" banworthy, but feeding to be ok? Does anybody truly believe that calling someone "bad" is ruining the game more than the fact that someone is 0/10? I just can't see any legitimate argument for that.

> [{quoted}](name=Riot Tantram,realm=NA,application-id=ZGEFLEUQ,discussion-id=ZZkQvApM,comment-id=000600000000,timestamp=2016-11-02T00:49:10.616+0000)
>
> Perma-ban is designed to remove players from the game. We no longer want them playing League of Legends because they hurt the experience of others.
> 
> The result of the experiment was actually 95% of the players being permabanned again. Not 80-90% getting reported before level 20.
> 
> The current punishment levels are as they are because if a player does not change their behavior after multiple warnings, they are not likely to change. We used to have other punishment levels in place, but all it did was delay the amount of time until a player arrived at perma-ban status. It did not help with reform rates, and ultimately allowed more games to be ruined.
> 
> There are diminishing reform rates at each level of penalty. The majority of players who get a chat restriction, never get any other penalty. Additionally, the vast majority of players never get any sort of penalty at all. Players that get penalties of any sort are by far the outlier.

An experiment failed 4+ years ago?.... I'm so glad scientists don't just quit and say GG after 1 failed experiment.....we would still be living in the dark ages.  >>

A) Riot are not scientists.

B) The experiment didn't fail in the scientific sense. In the scientific sense it was an extreme success, as the results were very conclusive. And very conclusive experiments with results that are commonly accepted in the scientific community actually are not repeated that often.
Granted, the fact that reproduction studies are not done often enough is a big problem, but it obviously is not keeping us in the dark ages as quite apparently we are not currently living in the dark ages. The problem we have today with lack of reproduction studies is also mostly related to P-hacking and the likes skewing with the accuracy of published science, which Riot has no incentive to do.
They're not trying to print papers in high impact journals. They're trying to improve their game. P-hacking accomplishes nothing in their case (and would be fairly difficult with such a simple setup). Which in turn brings us back to answer A): Riot are not scientists.

"Riot gives you one last final option to reform"

Riot gave you the option to reform after your chat bans. You were still toxic

Riot gave you the option to reform after your first suspension. You were still toxic

Riot gave you "one last final option to reform" after your 14 day ban. You were still toxic

Then you got perma banned and act like "oh but one MORE chance" would change anything. You would still be toxic, get banned, and then want another chance.

A 10-game chat restriction is like being sent to your room for the rest of the night. A two-week ban is like being grounded and not allowed to go out for those two-weeks. A permaban is like, snapping your neck, no more chances. See how that escalates? Haha.
Maybe you shoulda taken the first two hints

You talk like you are a kid and riot is your mum. 

We are talking about business here, if you shit talk someone in a restaurant (even if he started) the manager will kick you both out since he wants a nice atmosphere for his other customers. And if you do that twice you will be on the blacklist for the restaurant. This is about business.

If perma-banned players weren't willing to change after the chat bans and the 14-day ban, why should Riot think they're willing to change?

I believe the 14-day ban specifically tells you that the next punishment can be a permanent ban.

And the amount of money you spend should never influence how the system treats you.

I'm not asking for preferential treatment, I'm asking for a reformation of the rules that are meant to reform. I'm not spending my 14-day ban reflecting my in-game behavior, it's a game, people will get upset. The escalation from 14 days to eternity is a ridiculous jump. The bans do nothing, the chat restrictions are better because they limit how much you can say. But honestly, to reform toxicity, chat penalties would be best. Because there are tons of people who INTENTIONALLY play poorly or take actions to screw over their team and if they don't say anything in chat or appear friendly, they can get away with that. That kind of gameplay is far more toxic and less conducive to a positive gaming environment than reporting someone because they said "fuck you" and called you an "asshole" or what not. 

And it's not just about the money. It's about the time spent, the champions bought with IP, and the dreadful pain of leveling up from 0-30 where you have to deal with toxic, unskilled, overall inexperienced players. Which is a punishment in and of itself. In professional sports, nobody is getting banned for cursing. 

Plus, from a psychological standpoint, your behavior will not realistically change in 14 days. It can, but if toxicity is verbal, instituting permanent chat restriction or simply not allowing certain words to be "entered" would more effectively prevent and deter toxicity because you would have to find more appropriate language to use. If the aim is to reform. Is that not the goal? Reform not remove.

You are asking for preferential treatment though.

Those who can spend $50 get the extra chance at the end. Those who cannot don't.

You are already given a chance to reform. That's what the chat bans and 14-day ban is for. Any more than that and you're likely to forget why you were banned in the first place anyway.

It's a business. As a business move, you don't think a 50 dollar buyback and much less leniency would not reform players? The point is to reform, not remove. You could end up spending 50 dollars, then if you're extremely stupid and play 10 games and are reported 10 times, your account and everything is deleted. Riot gets 50 dollars, removes the person who clearly didn't try to behave better, win-win.

No. When it's the perma-ban, the point **_is_** to remove.

Riot has decided they would rather lose your business and hope you move to a different game. They don't want you interacting with the community anymore.

The purpose of the chat restrictions and the 14-day ban is to reform. Beyond that, you're too much trouble to give additional chances.

And what's more trouble? Someone who curses people off when they are intentionally feeding or playing like assholes and not listening to advice to improve their play, or someone who intentionally screws over their teammates for their own personal pleasure? The percentage of verbally toxic players and those whose gameplay is toxic is probably similar or greater in regards to the latter. You're saying you'd rather play with someone who feeds 10 kills, doesn't say a word, even when you try to communicate civilly with them, then play with someone who knows the mechanics and their champ, and calls out those people?

The 14-day ban doesn't reform, it punishes. There is no modification of behavior in removing something. It needs to be learned. If you believe 14-day bans and permanent bans are effective, then you also think the American prison system is a success.

> [{quoted}](name=Feniks,realm=NA,application-id=ZGEFLEUQ,discussion-id=ZZkQvApM,comment-id=000200000000000000000000,timestamp=2016-11-01T22:08:27.435+0000)
>
> And what's more trouble? Someone who curses people off when they are intentionally feeding or playing like assholes and not listening to advice to improve their play, or someone who intentionally screws over their teammates for their own personal pleasure?

There's a fundamental flaw with this logic though.  It assumes that the toxic person is automatically more skilled and correct if his/her opinion on how something in the match should be done differs from his/her teammates.  In my experience, many of the ragers are NOT in fact so much better at the game than the people they yell at.  They simply think they are, and begin to rage if their team does not do what they want them to.

> [{quoted}](name=VentressRedeemed,realm=NA,application-id=ZGEFLEUQ,discussion-id=ZZkQvApM,comment-id=0002000000000000000000000000,timestamp=2016-11-01T22:41:30.515+0000)

> There's a fundamental flaw with this logic though.  It assumes that the toxic person is automatically more skilled and correct if his/her opinion on how something in the match should be done differs from his/her teammates.  In my experience, many of the ragers are NOT in fact so much better at the game than the people they yell at.  They simply think they are, and begin to rage if their team does not do what they want them to.

Regardless of whether it's perceived differences in skill or actual differences in skill. Both are extremely frustrating and I think it's worth showing mercy after say a 6 month or 1 year period for them to really sit and understand what it means that there account will be gone if ANYTHING like what they did happens again.

On a personal note, I'm not much better than my team but things that make me rage are complete lack of warding all game or literally sitting there 3 feet from me while I try to 1v1, pinging for them to come with the hope they'll fire the ONE auto that I need to kill the person. Last game  I invaded and literally ran from 2 players past the midlaner and into our jungle where top and jg were sitting there twiddling their thumbs.  I only survived because they saw them sitting there and switched focus. Then we nearly get a double kill out of it but can't secure it because we started the fight so late. Midlaner of course didn't move and the support stayed bot. It wasn't enough to make me tilt because at this point I just expect everyone I'm matched with to be completely awful but it was enough to type what on earth are you guys thinking? Am I going to be alone like this all game? And the answer was yes, I was going to be. Was really glad I was on a Jhin and could pick people off from 10 miles away because I had zero peels and zero help.

The point being, whether it's ACTUAL skill differences or not. It doesn't matter. The frustration is what creates toxicity. And the frustration is due to people's inability to effectively teach the game (or at least how they think it should be played) in the span of one game to the person.  "Please ward here, take this objective, watch the map, swing bot with me, etc. etc. etc." is conveyed as "omg you suck" "are you dumb?" and "you fucked me over asshole". Sure there's actual trolls and maybe the guy who ran down mid and called everyone a %%% shouldn't be allowed to recover. But the guy who got frustrated with his team probably deserves that one last shot.

You don't follow the rules, you deserve to be banned. They set up the rules and you agreed to them. There's nothing else to it. 

The VAST majority of players never reach the level of getting permabanned, which means you'd have to cross some SERIOUS lines to get there.

Edit: Please don't downvote without replying. I'd love to discuss what you think is wrong with my statement.

I respect your opinion, but you act as if myself and others are akin to murderers or simply rage for the sake of raging. When in reality we're, well at least myself, are usually reacting to players who: 

1. Do not communicate.
2. Are feeding, and not accepting advice.
3. Feeding on purpose. 

My toxicity is normally reactive and not proactive. Also, sure there is a majority of players who don't get banned, but the percentage of those banned is greatly under exaggerated by Riot. The percentage is probably a lot higher than their "0.04%" or whatever of people are banned if you take into account those getting banned have to play quite frequently. Anyway. Not that important. 

I'm not here to justify my behavior, but propose a way to reclaim our accounts and reform our behaviors more productively than the system in place. 

By the way, the "rules" or the "Summoner's Code" are vaguely written and can be loosely interpreted in many different ways.

Like I said, you have to cross some really far lines in regards to toxicity, more than just calling someone trash, over many games to get to the point of perma'd. If you hadn't reformed by then, what reason does Riot see to give you yet another chance?

An honest question, do you think a 14-day ban and then a permanent ban is/would be more effective than replacing it with a word filter that prevents you from entering inappropriate words or a permanent chat restriction to reforming toxic players?

> [{quoted}](name=Feniks,realm=NA,application-id=ZGEFLEUQ,discussion-id=ZZkQvApM,comment-id=0001000000000000,timestamp=2016-11-01T21:53:39.433+0000)
>
> An honest question, do you think a 14-day ban and then a permanent ban is/would be more effective than replacing it with a word filter that prevents you from entering inappropriate words or a permanent chat restriction to reforming toxic players?

Inappropriate words aren't the problem. People reacting by being asshats is the problem.
